Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Materials World Network: Collaborative Research on Simple Forms of Quantum Turbulence - Production, Decay and Visualization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Turbulence in classical fluids is important and challenging both from a theory perspective and for many practical applications. This research, a collaboration between the University of Florida, Yale University, and the Universities of Lancaster, Manchester and Birmingham in the United Kingdom, aims to understand how classical turbulence is modified in a superfluid, such as liquid helium, in which flow is severely restricted by quantum conditions associated with the quantization of angular momentum and a complete lack of viscosity. Quantum turbulence has a character that depends on the temperature. Just below the superfluid transition temperature a superfluid behaves as a mixture of a normal (classical-like) fluid and a superfluid; either or both fluids can be turbulent, which gives rise to a rich variety of possible turbulent patterns At much lower temperatures only the superfluid component remains, exhibiting most clearly the fundamental aspects of quantum turbulence. The study of quantum turbulence would be greatly facilitated if the patterns of turbulent flow could be visualized. The use of micron-sized particles of hydrogen as tracers has been pioneered elsewhere, but the investigators in this project are implementing the use of much smaller particles in the form of metastable diatomic helium molecules, which will be observed by laser fluorescence. At temperatures somewhat below the superfluid transition such molecules are expected to follow the normal fluid, while at much lower temperatures they are expected to follow the quantized vortex motion in the superfluid component. In the earlier stages of the work the investigators will develop this technique for application in the more accessible temperature range where the molecules track the normal fluid, but where many important aspects of quantum turbulence have still to be studied and understood. The preliminary experiments will pave the way towards applications at lower temperatures. Also, since a very simple form of turbulence can be generated in the wake of a steadily moving grid, the investigators are developing techniques for moving a grid through superfluid helium at a very low temperature where the quantum turbulence involves only the normal fluid. The resulting turbulence will be studied on a global scale in two ways: observing the rate at which the superfluid heats up as a result of the decay of the turbulence; and using the scattering of ions to measure the rate at which the concentration of turbulent eddies decays.

Success of the proposed experiments is dependent on the development of close interactive collaboration between Florida (development of the moving grid and study of energy dissipation behind it), Yale and Manchester (visualization), Birmingham (theory), Lancaster and Manchester (decay of the concentration of turbulent eddies behind a moving grid). Students and postdoctoral associates from all labs will work in the other labs both to promote the overall effort and further to develop each researcher's capability. While the work is challenging because of the low temperature environment, the possible pay off is high, as an understanding of quantum turbulence may offer insights into classical turbulence which have heretofore escaped common understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trapping of He2* molecules on quantized vortices: We report the successful completion of the main goal of the rotating helium experiment, namely the determination of the trapping diameter of helium excimer molecules on quantized vortices at low temperatures. We have also shown that the excimers can be used as a means of decoration of quantized vortices and a probe of the principal macroscopic characteristic of the quantum turbulence -- the vortex line density in turbulent tangles. The experiment concept is shown below.  We have calculated the value for the trapping diameter of the excimers to be 2.7 times smaller than for charged vortex rings.  This corresponds to a value of 96 nm for temperatures T = 60 to 100 mK and at a pressure of P = 0.1 bar. This value is surprisingly large, as the size of the bubble comprising the molecule is just 1.3 nm. The large trapping diameter is very promising for future experiments, in which quantum turbulence could be imaged using laser-induced fluorescence of trapped helium excimer molecules.  In another series of experiments, we have demonstrated that the excimers can be used as tracer particles for turbulent tangles.  We have also carried out an extensive study of the times of flights of excimers in the absence of vorticity. The momentum relaxation distance for the excimers in superfluid helium is inversely proportional to the 8th power of temperature. This enabled us to scan from the ballistic regime below 100 mK to the fully developed diffusion above 200 mK.  The observed crossover between the two regimes is of particular general interest.

Visualization of fluid flow in superfluid helium: Visualization of fluid flow in superfluid helium is accomplished by imaging thin He2* molecule lines created by femtosecond laser pulses.  Experiments are performed in counterflow, where heat current drives normal fluid in one direction, and superfluid travels in the opposite direction. We show that, at relatively small velocities, where the superfluid is already turbulent, the flow of the normal remains laminar, but with a distorted velocity profile, while at a higher velocity there is a transition to turbulence. The form of the structure function differs significantly from that found in conventional turbulence. In this quantum fluid, we find that velocity correlations decay more strongly with distance than is found in classical turbulence. 

Transition Edge Sensors for helium excimer detection: Transition Edge Sensors (TESs) have been been developed as a tool to better characterize the helium excimer molecules used in visualization.  To this end, we have characterized a transition edge sensor designed for in-situ detection of individual He2* excimers. We find a critical temperature of 420 mK, an electrothermal time constant of 3 microseconds, and a total energy resolution (FWHM) of 1.5 eV. We observe the detector response to short laser pulses, and have developed a successful analysis strategy for extracting direct-TES-hit pulse areas from a much larger substrate hit background. Several bolometers were produced, all using Ti as the TES material. One bolometer had no extra coating, while the other two had Au and Pt coating respectively, for low-oxidation coatings. The TESs was then used to detect helium excimer molecules in superfluid helium. Excimers were produced using sharp tungsten needles as well as gamma-ray scattering. We find the most robust He2* signal when there is no additional surface layer. This is the first demonstration of bolometric detection of electronic excitations in superfluid helium.


Last Modified: 11/23/2015
Modified by: Daniel Mckinsey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Trapping of He2* molecules on quantized vortices: We report the successful completion of the main goal of the rotating helium experiment, namely the determination of the trapping diameter of helium excimer molecules on quantized vortices at low temperatures. We have also shown that the excimers can be used as a means of decoration of quantized vortices and a probe of the principal macroscopic characteristic of the quantum turbulence -- the vortex line density in turbulent tangles. The experiment concept is shown below. We have calculated the value for the trapping diameter of the excimers to be 2.7 times smaller than for charged vortex rings. This corresponds to a value of 96 nm for temperatures T = 60 to 100 mK and at a pressure of P = 0.1 bar. This value is surprisingly large, as the size of the bubble comprising the molecule is just 1.3 nm. The large trapping diameter is very promising for future experiments, in which quantum turbulence could be imaged using laser-induced fluorescence of trapped helium excimer molecules. In another series of experiments, we have demonstrated that the excimers can be used as tracer particles for turbulent tangles. We have also carried out an extensive study of the times of flights of excimers in the absence of vorticity. The momentum relaxation distance for the excimers in superfluid helium is inversely proportional to the 8th power of temperature. This enabled us to scan from the ballistic regime below 100 mK to the fully developed diffusion above 200 mK. The observed crossover between the two regimes is of particular general interest. Visualization of fluid flow in superfluid helium: Visualization of fluid flow in superfluid helium is accomplished by imaging thin He2* molecule lines created by femtosecond laser pulses. Experiments are performed in counterflow, where heat current drives normal fluid in one direction, and superfluid travels in the opposite direction. We show that, at relatively small velocities, where the superfluid is already turbulent, the flow of the normal remains laminar, but with a distorted velocity profile, while at a higher velocity there is a transition to turbulence. The form of the structure function differs significantly from that found in conventional turbulence. In this quantum fluid, we find that velocity correlations decay more strongly with distance than is found in classical turbulence. Transition Edge Sensors for helium excimer detection: Transition Edge Sensors (TESs) have been been developed as a tool to better characterize the helium excimer molecules used in visualization. To this end, we have characterized a transition edge sensor designed for in-situ detection of individual He2* excimers. We find a critical temperature of 420 mK, an electrothermal time constant of 3 microseconds, and a total energy resolution (FWHM) of 1.5 eV. We observe the detector response to short laser pulses, and have developed a successful analysis strategy for extracting direct-TES-hit pulse areas from a much larger substrate hit background. Several bolometers were produced, all using Ti as the TES material. One bolometer had no extra coating, while the other two had Au and Pt coating respectively, for low-oxidation coatings. The TESs was then used to detect helium excimer molecules in superfluid helium. Excimers were produced using sharp tungsten needles as well as gamma-ray scattering. We find the most robust He2* signal when there is no additional surface layer. This is the first demonstration of bolometric detection of electronic excitations in superfluid helium.
